Award.AwardTitle: HBCU RISE: Design of Nanostructures for Energy efficient Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Research Infrastructure for Science and Engineering (HBCU-RISE) activity within the Centers of Research Excellence in Science and Technology (CREST) program supports the development of research capability at HBCUs that offer doctoral degrees in science and engineering disciplines. HBCU-RISE projects have a direct connection to the long-term plans of the host department(s) and the institutional mission, and plans for expanding institutional research capacity as well as increasing the production of doctoral students in science and engineering. With support from the National Science Foundation, Alabama A&M University aims to address the energy crisis by developing energy efficient devices and power generators. Alabama A&M University will train at least four graduate and two undergraduate students, and a total six K-12 teachers and twelve secondary school students. This project will increase the number of Ph.D. students at Alabama A&M University by 30%. This project has the potential to contribute significantly to the pool of minority students trained in energy harvesting and nanoscience that is vital to the nation's energy infrastructure.

The proposed research involves the design of nanostructures and the fabrication of energy efficient devices for white light sources, thermoelectric power generators, and energy harvesters from ambient sources. The research objectives include: 1) improving infrastructure in Optics and Materials Science research; 2) designing nanostructured glasses with enhanced luminescence properties and demonstrating bright white light emission under low power diode laser excitation; 3) developing nano-structured multilayer and/or single layer Thermoelectric (TE) devices and TE waveguides for high temperatures applications; 4) fabricating and characterizing nanocomposite films; and 5) designing piezoelectric/pyroelectric generator system and fabricating cantilever and stack harvesters to demonstrate proof of concept. This research will enable Alabama A&M University to: (1) design efficient diode pumped white light sources and laser materials, which are free from pollution; (2) design more efficient thermoelectric power generators; and (3) develop clean energy sources. This project will expand the scientific literacy of all citizens on issues related to NSF's mission, scientific achievement, and technological advancements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project goals include infrastructure development, research, mentoring graduate and undergraduate students and educational outreach activities.   The grant money was used to upgrade laboratory facilities in Physics and Electrical Engineering departments.  The research includes the design of nanostructures and the fabrication of energy efficient devices for white light sources, thermoelectric power generators, and energy harvesters from ambient sources.

               We made a significant advance on the application of phosphors materials for diode pumped white light emission studies. We characterized rare-earth ion doped fluoride materials, borate glasses and phosphate glasses.  Fluoride materials embedded with Eu3+, Tb3+ or Dy3+ are able to generate white light under blue diode laser excitation.  The measured color coordinates are x = 0.322 and y = 0.340 for Dy3+-doped CaF2, x = 0.283 and y = 0.293 for LaF3: Eu3+ and x = 0.342 and y = 0.365 for LaF3: Tb3+. These values are close to those of sunlight for which x=0.33 and y=0.33. In fluoride materials the cut-off phonon frequency is small, 360 cm-1 and hence emission occurs from more than one excited level, thus generating white light. Borate or phosphate glasses embedded with Sm3+, Dy3+ and Tb3+ are found to be suitable candidates for white light generation.  Measured color coordinates of the glasses are found to be dependent on the glass composition.  Heat treatment was found to be effective in inducing silver nano particles which in turn enhanced the luminescence intensity of glasses. The cut-off phonon frequency of these glasses is more than 1000 cm-1 and hence non-radiative relaxation is predominat. So, two or more dopant ions are required for white light generation. 

Multilayered hetero-structured thermoelectric thin films were deposited using sputtering and electron beam systems. They were annealed at different temperatures to induce quantum structures in the multilayers to increase their efficiency. After the completion of thermoelectric properties of Ni/Bi2Te3/Sb2Te3/Ni, Si/Si+Sb, Si/Si+Ge, two new systems of Sb/Sb+SnO2 and Sn/Sn+SnO2 multilayer thin films have been characterized. Si/Si+Sb, Si/Si+Ge, Ni/Bi2Te3/Sb2Te3/Ni multilayer devices reached their highest figure of merit (efficiency) values of 2.6, 0.37, and 4x10-3, respectively at some annealed temperatures. The figure of merit, ZT of Sb/Sb+SnO2 multilayer thin films reached 1.54, the figure of merit of Sn/Sn+ SnO2 multilayer thin films reached 3.40. The ZT values are higher because heat treatment induced quantum structure in the samples which increased the Seebeck coefficient and electrical conductivity but decreased thermal conductivity. 

Ambient energy harvesting is achieved with piezoelectric materials which in turn can be used to power autonomous microelectronic devices.  In this study, nanocomposites of piezoelectric materials such as  lanthanum doped lead zirconate titanate (PLZT) and lead magnesium niobate–lead titanate (PMN-PT) with paint matrix was fabricated by a simple time and cost-effective conventional brushing technique. Furthermore, these nanocomposites could be conformed to any shape especially where sensors are required for angular or curvilinear shapes, which is a noteworthy achievement. The output voltage and power generated from PLZT/paint and PMN-PT/paint piezoelectric energy harvester is relatively small (51.7 mV and ~0.38 µW and 65 mV and ~1.0 nW), the possibility of enhancing it by the application of thermal vibrations, proof mass, increasing content and particle connectivity and increasing dimensions. The output voltage and power of PMN-PT/paint nanocomposite films-based cantilever harvester increased from 53.6 mV to 61.6 mV for a 3°C increase in temperature at a mechanical vibration of 61 Hz, and a load resistance of 4 MΩ. Our research should be beneficial in powering future flexible low power devices. Thus, societal benefits will be of saving money, and saving environment via not dumping of drained batteries.

            Six graduate students (3 male and 3 female) were supported by this grant. Among those four students completed M.S. thesis work and two students completed Ph.D. dissertation work. Students presented their results at national and international conferences and were co-authors on several publications. About 10 undergraduate students also participated in research activities. Physics curriculum was upgraded by adding new courses on energy harvesting and nanoscience. One investigator published three books on topics related to energy harvesting. A total of 26 High school students were exposed to the ongoing research activities. High school students spent a month working with the project scientists. Three summer workshops were held on Nanoscience and Technology.  Workshop speakers were invited from the regional universities. Several undergraduate students, graduate students and faculty members attended the workshops.
